+ */
+public final class IdentifyLabelsConfiguration {
+    private static final String CONFIG_NAME = "identifyLabels";

nodes.bodyText: This is weird, having one of these in a const, and the other not. I'd stick with a single approach, whichever you choose.

I simply wanted to make CONFIG_NAME a constant because it gets used twice in the code instead of once like the other keys haha. Also, they denote different levels in the JSON document, so I figured the lowest level nodes don't deserve a special treatment.
Under what conditions is it valuable to provide a non-LabelType object, here? I see later you have some control flow around a ClassCastException.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -104,12 +107,19 @@ public void translate(
      * @param onError triggered upon encountering error
      */
     public void detectLabels(
-            @NonNull LabelType type,
+            @NonNull IdentifyAction type,

nodes.bodyText: I figured it might be confusing to have people provide IdentifyActionType everywhere except when doing it for label detection and text detection, so I wanted IdentifyActionType.DETECT_LABELS to be a valid entry also. Besides, the configuration value will be always ignored if the user is forced to supply an explicit value here all the time, and I figured IdentifyActionType.DETECT_LABELS is a great choice to use as the default option.

      */
     public void detectLabels(
-            @NonNull LabelType type,
+            @NonNull IdentifyAction type,

nodes.bodyText: How about, "Celebrity detection has not been configured." Disabled sounds more like it has been turned off explicitly, or is has been made unavailable by policy.
There is already an explicit "celebrityDetectionEnabled" flag under "identifyEntities" configuration, so I think this message is appropriate.
This is a great recovery suggestion.
